description: From Middle English laughen, laghen, from (Anglian) Old English hlæhhan, hlehhan, (West Saxon) hliehhan, from Proto-West Germanic *hlahhjan, from Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

entries.meaning: An expression of mirth particular to the human species; the sound heard in laughing; laughter.
examples: And the loud laugh that spoke the vacant mind.

entries.meaning: Something that provokes mirth or scorn.
examples: “And this rug,” he says, stomping on an old rag carpet. “How much do you suppose that cost?” ¶ It was my first guess, so I said fifty dollars. ¶ “That’s a laugh,” he said. “I paid two thousand for that rug.”
Outhwaite is a good laugh, yes, she knows how to smile: but deep down, she really is strong and stern.

verbs.description: laugh (third-person singular simple present laughs, present participle laughing, simple past and past participle laughed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To show mirth, satisfaction, or derision, by peculiar movement of the muscles of the face, particularly of the mouth, causing a lighting up of the face and eyes, and usually accompanied by the emission of explosive or chuckling sounds from the chest and throat; to indulge in laughter.
examples: The roars of laughter which greeted his proclamation were of two qualities; some men laughing because they knew all about cuckoo-clocks, and other men laughing because they had concluded that the eccentric Jake had been victimised by some wise child of civilisation.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively, obsolete) To be or appear cheerful, pleasant, mirthful, lively, or brilliant; to sparkle; to sport.
(intransitive, followed by "at") To make an object of laughter or ridicule; to make fun of; to deride; to mock.
examples: On the corner is a banker with a motorcar / The little children laugh at him behind his back

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affect or influence by means of laughter or ridicule.
(transitive) To express by, or utter with, laughter.
examples: Fairfax addressed her as "my lady," she laughed her musical laugh, and glanced up at a picture of Gerald with eyes full of exultation.
